channel.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:27, topic:507649”][quote author=Arcik link=topic=625884.msg4259768#msg4259768 date=1363350171]

I’ve always thought of Brackets as: { } Same with Braces.
and I call these: ( ) parenthesis.
Lol.

Your slightly correct, but I’m referring back to what I learnt in school. Parenthesis is the parent word.
[/quote]

Well, what I learned in school is that these ( ) are parenthesis. And then I learned in programming, that these { } are brackets[/quote]
You’re all correct to an extent. While () or open brackets are referred to as parenthesis, so are {} or curly brackets or braces. This really is a pointless argument (for want of a better word) considering everyone is correct.

Read full topic
item.source: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)

and I call these: ( ) parenthesis.
Lol.
[/quote]

Your slightly correct, but I’m referring back to what I learnt in school. Parenthesis is the parent word.[/quote]

Well, what I learned in school is that these ( ) are parenthesis. And then I learned in programming, that these { } are brackets

if (random > 11) { System.out.println("Random is currently " + random); } else { System.out.println("Random is smaller then 12!"); }

I mean, I don’t program anymore so I can’t really critique. But it’s just a thought.[/quote]
Haven’t seen you on here since like 2010 hahaha damn.

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“relexlawl, post:21, topic:507649”][quote author=Sup22211 link=topic=625884.msg4258622#msg4258622 date=1363192533]

Now this is definantly a tutorial. Helpful for the noons who think RSPS is its language. :rolleyes:

IKR why people thinking its a programing language…LOL
What wrong with this code?

public void SwitchST(int num){ switch(num){ case 0: System.out.println("The num is: 0"); break; case 1: System.out.println("The num is: 1"); break; case 2: System.out.println("The num is: 2"); break; } }
[/quote]

What’s wrong with that?

That you’re asking something you’re already answered yourself… (asking what the number is when you’re already putting it in the param…not to mention methods conventionally start with lowercase.

This ‘tutorial’ is just teaching people bad habits, nothing wrong with javadocs.[/quote]

I didn’t even look at this code, and care to point out what i done wrong/bad habit?

Edit: I’m also going to re-do aspects of this, since the word limit kinda screwed me over i’ll add conventions etc instead of w.e.

Read full topic
item.source: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

[quote=“Sup22211, post:7, topic:507649”][quote author=arham 4 link=topic=625884.msg4258621#msg4258621 date=1363192291]
Now this is definantly a tutorial. Helpful for the noons who think RSPS is its language. :rolleyes:
[/quote]
IKR why people thinking its a programing language…LOL
What wrong with this code?

public void SwitchST(int num){ switch(num){ case 0: System.out.println("The num is: 0"); break; case 1: System.out.println("The num is: 1"); break; case 2: System.out.println("The num is: 2"); break; } }[/quote]

What’s wrong with that?

That you’re asking something you’re already answered yourself… (asking what the number is when you’re already putting it in the param…not to mention methods conventionally start with lowercase.

This ‘tutorial’ is just teaching people bad habits, nothing wrong with javadocs.

instad bla == true;

and also

You can ask a gmod to clean the topic up and leave your posts so you can edit them and then you’ll have all of the tutorial in one line. Just pm one of them and I’m sure they’ll do something for you if everyone else is okay with having their posts removed.

item.dc:creator: @Sup22211 Sup22211
item.description:
@Sup22211 wrote:

[quote=“Arcik, post:1, topic:507649”]private boolean starter;

[code=java]
public void giveStarter() {
if (starter == false) {
addItem(4151, 1);
addItem(11694, 1):

    [b]starter == true;[/b]
    sendMessage("You have just received a start kit!");

} else if (starter == true) {
    sendMessage("You have already claimed your starter kit!");
}

}[/code][/quote]
Should be ‘starter = true;’

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:13, topic:507649”][quote author=arham 4 link=topic=625884.msg4258621#msg4258621 date=1363192291]
EDIT2: Mention sleeping a thread. Personally, I just sleep the Thread for a delay instead of doing your way. Like this:

public static void main(String args[]) throws InterruptedException { Thread.sleep(5000); // Makes a 5 second delay by milliseconds. System.out.println("It has been 5 seconds now: HELLO!!!"); // Prints out something. }
EDIT3: Mention String[] args can be changed to a different name like String[] tacos.

EDIT4: Tell them String[] args is the command line.
[/quote]

To add. All you need to do and then you’re done.[/quote]

I added a brief on Thread.sleep but there’s so much to explain, totally missed out logical operators etc

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Do you guys want me to go in real death and literally teach the language lol?

And how about this stuff:
Generic class
Implements, throwable, catch clause, @Override expersions
Conditions
Proper stuff with static (e.g. static class/import etc)
Annotations
Hex’s
Wrappers
Generics
Swing
Events
Networking
Formatting
Keys
[size=18pt]ETCETERA[/size]

Tbfh if I was to explain everything in real detail with examples, scenarios etc., would the community budge?
I would love if you guys could comment/inbox a contribution towards this thread and point out mistakes I may of made (I noticed some) etc etc

Read full topic

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“arham 4, post:6, topic:507649”]Now this is definantly a tutorial. Helpful for the noobs who think RSPS is its language. :rolleyes:

But I also agree with the others. In order for this to qualify for a featured tutorial (if not, a noob-friendly tutorial) you must explain every bit of code. Even the code must explain it itself (with comments) and then you basically reinterprit the comments in a differant style.

EDIT: Make a more friendly title. Noons get scared from those titles. Try:
Concepts While Coding - A Beginner’s Walkthrough on How to Program
Or you can try:
The Beginner’s How-to: On how to program.[/quote]

This is only 20% done (made that percentage up) I have so much more to add and it’s super time consuming! I’ll be doing a programming tutorial in General Programming section (if that’s the correct section) soon.

Sup22211:

What wrong with this code?

I don’t like it.

Read full topic

arham 4:

Now this is definantly a tutorial. Helpful for the noons who think RSPS is its language. :rolleyes:

IKR why people thinking its a programing language…LOL
What wrong with this code?

public void SwitchST(int num){ switch(num){ case 0: System.out.println("The num is: 0"); break; case 1: System.out.println("The num is: 1"); break; case 2: System.out.println("The num is: 2"); break; } }

item.source: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

Now this is definantly a tutorial. Helpful for the noobs who think RSPS is its own language. :rolleyes:

But I also agree with the others. In order for this to qualify for a featured tutorial (if not, a noob-friendly tutorial) you must explain every bit of code. Even the code must explain it itself (with comments) and then you basically reinterprit the comments in a differant style.

EDIT: Make a more friendly title. Noobs get scared from those titles. Try:
Concepts While Coding - A Beginner’s Walkthrough on How to Program
Or you can try:
The Beginner’s How-to: On how to program.

EDIT2: Mention sleeping a thread. Personally, I just sleep the Thread for a delay instead of doing your way. Like this:

public static void main(String args[]) throws InterruptedException { Thread.sleep(5000); // Makes a 5 second delay by milliseconds. System.out.println("It has been 5 seconds now: HELLO!!!"); // Prints out something. }
EDIT3: Mention String[] args can be changed to a different name like String[] tacos.

EDIT4: Tell them String[] args is the command line.

Read full topic
item.source: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Sup22211, post:2, topic:507649”]4 Things :
1.You can explain to them that the “public void main(String[] args) {” basicly run the application and if you dont have it you cant run it. (maybe you did explain this but i didn’t see)
2.Ah i see i gave you an idea whit the wait 5 seconds and then something will happen. Cool lol
3. add to your TODO list a “void” with parameters.
4.Show them a simple switch statement like this:

public void SwitchST(int num){
switch(num){
case 0:
System.out.println("The num is: 0");
break;
case 1:
System.out.println("The num is: 1");
break;
case 2:
System.out.println("The num is: 2");
break;
        }
}

And more…[/quote]

I explained it somewhere.
No you didn’t give me the idea
switch statements are in my TODO list (also your “simple” example is kinda crappy lol)

[quote=“Fire capez, post:3, topic:507649”]How this could be improved:
Explain method return types (i.e void is a method with no return type)
Explain the concept of a compiler error and why a missing brace will print 100 errors.
Explain operator precedence.
Explain the ternary operator.
Explain why different data types exist, i.e why have both byte and int?
Explain the concept of an object.
Explain the concept of an IDE.
Briefly explain the concept of bytecode and how compilation and interpretation actually works.[/quote]

I crossed out what I’m not going to do, but I’ll deffo take considerations on that list. Its just a big pain in the ass trying to give a good example and definition without going into some nerdy explanation which won’t make sense lol.

  • I’ll be doing all sorts of requests if you guys want and i’ll do a thread update status too.

Edit: when i read through this again, I noticed some code errors which i’ll be fixing too!

Read full topic
item.source: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)

item.title: Basic Java concepts - (rookies guide, tips and tricks)
item.dc:creator: @Sup22211 Sup22211
item.description:
@Sup22211 wrote:

[quote=“Fire capez, post:3, topic:507649”]How this could be improved:
Explain method return types (i.e void is a method with no return type)[/quote]
Isn’t this a boolean method?
public boolean IDK(int i){
i = 1;
if(i == 1){
return true;
}
if(i == 0){
return false;
}
}
